On-site hydrogen-rich gas production from diesel: A comprehensive study on catalyst development with nickel and diverse metal oxides (MgO, La2O3, CeO2, SiO2) supported on alumina Nurbanu Cakiryilmaz Sahingoz Writing – original draft Visualization Validation Methodology Investigation Formal analysis a Kerem Talu Writing – review & editing Visualization Validation Software Methodology Investigation b Nuray Oktar Writing – review & editing Supervision Methodology Investigation a ⁎ Timur Dogu Writing – review & editing Supervision Methodology Investigation b Ibrahim Pamuk Resources Project administration Conceptualization c a Department of Chemical Engineering, Graduate School of Natural and Applied Science, Gazi University, Ankara, Turkey Department of Chemical Engineering, Graduate School of Natural and Applied Science, Gazi University Ankara Turkey Department of Chemical Engineering, Graduate School of Natural and Applied Science, Gazi University, Ankara, Turkey b Department of Chemical Engineering, Middle East Technical University, Ankara, Turkey Department of Chemical Engineering, Middle East Technical University Ankara Turkey Department of Chemical Engineering, Middle East Technical University, Ankara, Turkey c LENTATEK Uzay Havacılık ve Teknoloji, Ankara, Turkey LENTATEK Uzay Havacılık ve Teknoloji Ankara Turkey LENTATEK Uzay Havacılık ve Teknoloji, Ankara, Turkey ⁎ Corresponding author. The study aimed to investigate the impact of nickel-incorporating diverse metal oxides (MgO, La2O3, CeO2, SiO2) supported on alumina on the Diesel steam reforming reaction. Catalytic activity tests were performed within a reaction period of 6 h at 800°C and atmospheric pressure. The amount of catalyst is 30 gr in each experiment corresponding to a LHSV value of 0.2 hr−1. The tests proved that the performances of Ni-containing La2O3 and CeO2-supported catalysts were highly stable and active in steam reforming of Diesel, giving complete conversion. The incorporation of CeO2 (20 % wt) into Al2O3 support resulted in a significant reduction in the amount of coke formation from 0.85 % to 0.26 %. In order to investigate catalyst stability, time-on stream tests extending to 6 days, totaling 36 hours were performed using 5Ni@10La2O3-Al2O3. As a result of the long-term stability test, no deactivation has been observed under the test conditions despite very few amounts of carbon (1.33 wt%) formed. When comparing the short-term and long-term tests, similar syn-gas production results were observed, along with approximately the same amount of carbon formation. Graphical Abstract Keywords Hydrogen Diesel Steam reforming Nickel Metal oxide support Data availability Data will be made available on request. 1 Introduction Industrial and technological advancements are directly related to the use of low-cost clean energy. Therefore, energy has transcended from being only a commercial tool to directly affecting the quality of life of society. The rising global population, technological advancements, and increasing living standards are the primary reasons for the depletion of primary energy sources [1–3]. In addition to this, as technology advances, there is an increasing demand for alternative energy carriers such as hydrogen. According to a study by IRENA (International Renewable Energy Agency), the demand for hydrogen in 2050 would be six times higher than in 2020 [4]. Due to the economic and environmental concerns about our world's future, there is an increasing emphasis on alternative energy research [5–7]. When considering clean and alternative energy technologies, one of the popular methods today is electricity generation using fuel cell technology [8–10]. The technological importance of fuel cells stems from their ability to provide clean energy, increase energy distribution efficiency, and reduce environmental pollutants and greenhouse gas emissions. The hydrogen required for fuel cell operation can be produced from fossil fuels or renewable sources. In recent years, on-site production of hydrogen has become prominent for fuel cell usage [11–13]. When traditional fuels (gasoline, Diesel, etc.) are used for on-site hydrogen production, problems related to hydrogen storage are avoided. Additionally, on-site hydrogen production from traditional fuels is more economical in today's conditions, as traditional fuels have a higher volumetric energy density than hydrogen [14–16]. The studies have given priority to research on reforming traditional fuels such as Diesel and jet fuels for the production of hydrogen-rich gas. [17–25]. These fuels are used in heavy vehicles, aircraft, and ships. In addition, they are preferred as logistic fuels in military applications. Although Diesel is favored for its very high power density, hydrogen content, and widespread logistics, certain challenges are present in hydrogen production due to the nature of Diesel fuel which composed of saturated and aromatic hydrocarbons in uncertain proportion. Components with high number carbon atom in Diesel cause coke formation, reducing catalyst activity and system efficiency. [26–28]. In addition to coke formation, sulfur compounds present in Diesel affect the activity of the catalyst and poison the electrodes of the fuel cell [29,30]. Despite its disadvantages, Diesel is a suitable and portable hydrogen source for fuel cell applications due to its easy and safe logistics, having the highest energy density and widespread use among the traditional hydrocarbon fuels[26,31,32]. Due to the complex structure of Diesel, experimental studies have been undertaken using alternative hydrocarbons, including decane, decalin, tetradecane, n-heptane, n-decane, and n-hexadecane, as potential replacements for Diesel [18,33–35]. Steam reforming of Diesel is a highly complex process with several side reactions. Possible reactions of Diesel have been illustrated in previous studies [21,30]. In this study, the possible side reactions are provided in Table 1. Even though the primary aim in the steam reforming reactions (Eq. (1)) of hydrocarbons is hydrogen production, carbon monoxide, carbon dioxide, and/or methane always form as a result of undesirable side reactions. (1) CmHn + mH2O ↔ (m+ n /2) H2 + mCO Steam Reforming Carbon monoxide formation is observed at high temperatures due to the reverse water gas shift (Eq. (2)), reverse methanation (Eq. (3)), and reverse dry methane reforming reactions (Eq. (6)). Methane, on the other hand, forms at lower temperatures through reactions (Eq. (3)), (Eq. (5)), and (Eq. (6)) [36]. Another mechanism for methane formation is mentioned as the ∝-scission reaction [10,33]. Various reactions such as the irreversible decomposition of Diesel to ethylene or other olefins, ketonization reactions leading to the formation of acetone and ketene, methane, and coke formation reactions through the Boudouard reaction (Eq. (14)) and methane cracking (Eq. (9)) reactions must also be considered along with steam reforming [37–39]. The formation of coke may lead to catalyst deactivation and reactor clogging. Hence, developing a catalyst with high activity and resistance to coke formation is of vital importance. When reviewing literature studies, it is observed that studies on the reforming of Diesel with steam are comparatively less when compared to those on autothermal reforming [20,31,34,36,40–45]. Results reported in the recent literature showed that Pt, Pd, Rh, Ru, and Ni-based catalysts gave high activity in steam reforming of Diesel [17–19,28,36,42,45–49]. Among these catalysts, Ru-based catalyst exhibited high activity and selectivity toward hydrogen production [17,18]. Due to the high price of noble metals, the activity of non-noble metals such as Co, Ni, etc. was also utilized in previous studies [26–28,36]. Due to its low cost and high activity, Ni-based catalysts attracted the major attention of researchers in steam reforming reactions [50,51]. However, a significant amount of coke formation was reported in the steam reforming of Diesel over Ni-based catalysts [19,28,30]. Particularly in recent years, efforts have been made to minimize carbon formation by working with monometallic or bimetallic Ni-based catalysts which consist of metal oxide [6,17,36,42,45–47]. Li et al. addressed issues such as carbon accumulation and metal sintering by impregnating additives containing metal oxide [52]. The main objectives of the present study were to obtain detailed comparative information for the activities of Ni-impregnated metal oxide (MgO, SiO2, CeO2, La2O3) supported alumina catalysts in steam reforming of Diesel. Within the scope of this study, catalyst activity tests have been carried out on sub-industrial scales using 30 g of catalyst, differs from most of the studies in literature where, catalytic activity tests have been examined by using about 0.1–1 g catalyst on a laboratory scale. Moreover, when the literature on the subject is examined, it is seen that the number of studies working with actual Diesel fuel is limited. This study differs from others in terms of novelty by measuring the performance and coke minimization in real practice using commercial Diesel fuel. It was aimed to develop a reforming catalyst with reduced deactivation achieving continuous on-site hydrogen-rich gas production using Diesel fuel as the hydrogen source. 2 Experimental section 2.1 Catalysts synthesis In this study, cylindrical gamma alumina (SA 6173) and silicon oxide are obtained from the Saint Gobain Company. The wet impregnation method was employed in the preparation of all nickel-containing catalysts synthesized as part of the study. Catalyst naming is expressed as "weight percent metal content@weight percent metal oxide content-support material (Al2O3)"; as, 5Ni@10La2O3-Al2O3. The number 10 indicates that La2O3 was impregnated onto the alumina support at a weight percentage of 10 %, and the number five indicates that nickel was impregnated onto the 10La2O3-Al2O3 support at a weight percentage of 5 %. 5Ni@SiO2-Al2O3 catalyst was prepared by adding nickel in a 5 % by-weight ratio to the commercially purchased support containing 75 % SiO2 and 25 % Al2O3. The catalysts prepared within the scope of the study, their loaded metal ratios, and the synthesis method are provided in Table 2. In this study, La2O3, SiO2, MgO, and CeO2 additives were chosen to keep the coke amount at a minimum level and to ensure a homogeneous distribution of metals on the catalyst surface. For the preparation of lanthanum-containing catalysts, the lanthanum source (LaN3O9.6H2O, Sigma-Aldrich) was used, while for the preparation of cerium-supported catalysts, the cerium source (Ce(NO3)3.6H2O, Merck) was utilized. For the magnesium-containing catalyst, the magnesium source (Mg(NO3)2.6H2O, Merck) was impregnated onto the alumina support. To observe the effect of lanthanum oxide amount, lanthanum oxide was added to the alumina support in different proportions (by weight %5, 10, and 20). Similarly, in order to see the effect of the cerium oxide amount, cerium oxide was added in 3 different proportions by weight %5, 10, and 20. After the preparation of these catalysts, a 5 % Ni addition was made using the impregnation method to increase activity. All synthesized catalysts were prepared following wet impregnation routes [50]. Mesoporous γ- alumina support (calcined at 900 °C) material was first dispersed in deionized water. In the case of synthesis of the catalyst containing 5 % Ni, nickel precursor (Ni(NO3).2H2O, technic) was separately dissolved in deionized water and this solution was added into the catalyst support mixture. Evaporation of water was then achieved at 40–50 °C while stirring. Materials were calcined for 6 h at 900°C in a muffle furnace and then reduced at 900 °C in a flow of hydrogen for 4 h, before the reaction tests. 2.2 Catalyst characterization Synthesized materials in this study were characterized by N2 adsorption-desorption, X-ray diffraction (XRD), Scanning electron microscope (SEM), and thermal analysis (TGA-DTA) of used catalysts gave information about the coke deposition on the catalytic materials. The nickel incorporated catalyst is reduced at 900 °C in a flow of hydrogen for 4 h before the characterization tests. The X-ray diffraction (XRD) analysis of the synthesized materials was performed using a Rigaku Ultima-IV diffractometer with a CuKα radiation source. The scanning range of 2ϴ was set between 10° and 90° with a scanning speed of 1°/min. Nitrogen adsorption-desorption analysis was performed to determine the physical properties of the synthesized catalysts, such as surface area, average pore diameter, and average pore volume. In the adsorption-desorption analysis, the "Quantochrome Autosorp 6 Physical Adsorption" instrument was used. The analysis was conducted at a temperature of 77 K over various nitrogen relative pressure ranges. All samples were degassed under vacuum conditions (3 hours at 120°C) before analysis to remove impurities in their pores. SEM analysis was used to determine the morphological structure of the synthesized catalysts. The analysis was conducted using the QUANTA 400 F Field Emission SEM high-resolution scanning electron microscope. 2.3 Catalyst testing in the reformer reactor system The main components which are used in reforming experiments are presented in Fig. 1. Ultrapure water obtained by Barnstead Nanopure Diamond Water System with a conductivity of 0.056 μS/cm and Diesel fuel containing ultra-low sulfur of 10 ppm max is acquired from a local gas station (OPET). Water and Diesel are fed to the experimental system by using HPLC pumps. Water is degasified before being used in the experiment in order to avoid any fluctuations in the flow rate in the pump due to gasification from dissolved air. The flow rates of water and Diesel are set to 0.95 mL/min and 0.15 mL/min respectively by the local PC. The flow rates are adjusted to obtain a steam/carbon (S/C) ratio of 6, assuming Diesel having the formulation of C17H36. Water and Diesel are introduced to the evaporator, which is made of a pipe full of inert material to increase heat transfer area and installed in an electrical heated oven, to keep the mixture temperature constant at 450°C for complete evaporation. The reactants are then heated up to 650°C in the pre-heater oven while passing from a spiral pipe. The feeding temperature of the reactants is determined after conducting several experiments. In these trials water and Diesel are fed to the system without a reactor. Then by increasing the pre-heater temperature gradually starting from 450°C, the temperature at which thermal decomposition became significant was determined. It was deduced from these trials that the optimal temperature is 650°C to avoid thermal cracking reactions. Above this point, a significant rise was spotted in the reaction rate of the thermal decomposition of Diesel into smaller hydrocarbon molecules. Catalytic conversion of Diesel and water into the synthesis gas is examined in a tubular reactor made of stainless steel of 316, having an inner diameter of 25 mm, and loaded with the catalyst to be subjected to analysis. The amount of catalyst is 30 gr in each experiment corresponding to a LHSV value of 0.2 hr−1. Reaction temperature is held at a constant temperature of 800°C via an electrical-heated furnace and the temperature of the catalyst bed is monitored with a K-type thermocouple located in the middle zone. Water and unconverted Diesel are condensed in a condenser cooled with circulated water after leaving the reformer portion. The exit gaseous flow rate was measured by a wet gas meter, Ritter TG1, and spot samples were taken during experiments for gas analysis. Reforming products were analyzed by an Agilent 6890 gas chromatography (GC). It is not connected online to the reaction system. Gas samples are taken from the line at specific time intervals and analyzed with the GC. Permanent gases (H2, CO, CO2, and N2) are analyzed with a thermal conductivity detector (TCD) and hydrocarbon gases (CH4, C2H4, C2H6, C3H6, C3H8) are analyzed with a flame ionization detector (FID). 2.3.1 Parameters Liquid hourly space velocity (LHSV, Eq.(19)) and the molar steam-to-carbon ratio (S/C, Eq. (20)) are calculated as follows: (19) LHSV = Q feed m cat (20) S / C = n H 2 O n diesel , C The catalyst performance was evaluated by mainly two parameters, namely molar conversion of Diesel (Eq. (21)) and percent yield of hydrogen (Eq. (22)). The parameters are calculated as follows: (21) X diesel = n diesel , reacted n diesel , fed (22) Y H 2 = n H 2 , produced n diesel , fed The hydrogen yield is obtained from the stoichiometric calculation of moles of hydrogen gas produced per mole of Diesel from steam reforming reaction by using C17H36 as Diesel surrogate molecule. The global steam reforming reaction considering the sum of steam reforming and water gas shift reactions, for C17H36 is given below. Therefore, the yield would be 52 mol H2/mol Diesel that is calculated from stoichiometric coefficient. (23) C 17 H 36 + 34 H 2 O → 17 C O 2 + 52 H 2 3 Results and discussion 3.1 Catalyst characterization Physical properties of MgO, CeO2, La2O3, and SiO2 supports and Ni-impregnated catalysts are given in Table 3. The surface area, pore diameter, and pore volume values of the cylindrical gamma alumina support material with an average diameter of 3 mm and length of 6 mm were obtained from the purchasing company. Arslan et al. also used the same commercial alumina in their study, and it was observed that there was no significant change in its structure after calcination [26]. The surface areas of the synthesized catalysts vary between 78 and 200 m2/g. It is observed that the surface area of commercial gamma alumina catalyst decreases with the addition of metal oxide (CeO2, MgO, La2O3) to the alumina structure. When the nickel amount was kept constant and the lanthanum ratio was changed, it was observed that, as the amount of lanthanum increased, the decrease in the surface area was further increased. Similar results were obtained for catalysts containing CeO2. Pore volumes of the support materials also decreased as a result of metal impregnation (Table 3). Such a decrease in surface area and pore volume values indicates that some of the pores in the catalyst structure were closed by the Ni and metal oxides. Along with the reduction in surface area and pore volume, an increase in pore diameter is also observed. The main reason for this observation is the clogging of the micropores present in Al2O3 support, as a result of the impregnation of CeO2 or La2O3. The mesopores, on the other hand, have slightly reduced in size due to impregnation, leading to a higher value of mean pore diameter. Similar results for CeO2-supported catalysts were also observed by Arslan et al. [26]. Nitrogen adsorption-desorption isotherms of CeO2, La2O3, and SiO2 catalyst supports and Ni-impregnated catalysts are given in Fig. 2. The nitrogen (N2) adsorption-desorption isotherms determined at different relative pressures (P/Po) for the synthesized catalysts are consistent with Type IV, indicating that the synthesized catalysts have a mesoporous structure. The hysteresis loop in the materials is Type H1 according to the IUPAC definition [50]. Such types of hysteresis loops are typically observed in mesoporous materials. As shown in Fig. 3, the pore size distributions of support materials and the reduced Ni-impregnated catalysts were quite wide. In the case of all synthesized catalysts apart from 5Ni@SiO2-Al2O3, a monodisperse pore size distribution was observed at a lower pore size range. In fact, the average mesopore diameter of this material was found as between 9 and 17 nm. The X-ray diffraction patterns carried out to determine the crystal structure of the cylindrical support material purchased commercially from the Saint-Gobain company are provided in the study conducted by Arslan et al. [26]. In the XRD pattern of the alumina support, which was calcined in a muffle furnace at 900℃ for 6 hours, 5 main characteristic peaks belonging to γ-Al2O3 (2θ: 19.33°, 37.5°, 45.6°, 67.0° and 85.0°) are observed. The X-ray diffraction patterns of the reduced 5 % Ni catalysts supported Al2O3 containing different ratios of La2O3 (by weight %5, 10, and 20) are presented in Fig. 4. The MATCH program (Crystal Impact) was used for the identification of peaks obtained from XRD results. These results have been confirmed with data taken from the literature. To observe the effect of metal loading on the structure, the XRD pattern of the 10La2O3-Al2O3 support is also given in the Supporting Material. It is observed that only the peaks corresponding to the γ-Al2O3 structure are present in the XRD pattern of the 10La2O3-Al2O3. This result indicates that the lanthanum oxide is well-dispersed in the catalyst structure, and its crystal size is smaller than what the XRD equipment can detect. This result has been confirmed with SEM analysis given in Table 5. According to Match results, in the wide-angle XRD patterns of the Ni-containing La2O3-Al2O3 catalysts, characteristic peaks related to the alumina structure (2θ: 32.82°, 39.40°, 46.02°, 66.88°) are observed. Kanwal et al. reported that the X-ray diffraction peaks of aluminum oxide at 2θ = 32.66°, 37.60°, 39,56°, 45.79°, and 67.1° correspond to the reflection from (111), (220), (311), (400) and (440) planes. These are the characteristic peaks of the γ-Al2O3 phase with cubic structure and matched with JCPDS (file no. 29–63). The accuracy of the Match program has been verified with data obtained from the JCPDS card (no. 29–63) [53]. The presence of these characteristic peaks after metal loading indicates that the alumina support retains its mesoporous structure. This result demonstrates that Ni-containing catalysts were successfully synthesized without disrupting the regular pore structure of La2O3-Al2O3. In the literature, characteristic peaks for elemental nickel are given as 2θ: 44.6°, 52.1°, 76.6° [2]. Three characteristic peaks (2θ: 44.46°, 51.79°, and 76.3°) corresponding to elemental Ni metal have been observed in the wide-angle XRD patterns of the catalysts. These peaks, specific to elemental nickel, are an indication that the nickel present in the regular pore structure of La2O3-Al2O3 was reduced with H2 gas following the reduction process. In the XRD analysis of the reduced 5 % Ni catalysts supported Al2O3 containing different ratios of CeO2 (by weight %5, 10, and 20) catalysts, the diffraction peaks observed at 2θ values of 44.58°, 51.88° and 76.52° were attributed to metallic Ni. Ashok et al. showed that the TPR profile of the unreduced catalysts showed that Ni particles in the synthesized catalysts begin to be reduced over 790 °C [54]. XRD results supported the TPR profile by showing the diffraction peaks belonging to metallic nickel. In the same XRD pattern of these catalysts, characteristic peaks are related to the alumina structure (2θ: 19.46°, 31.34°, 37.24°, 45.9°, 60.2° and 67.28°) and tetragonal CeAlO3 structure (2θ: 23.68°, 33.66°, 41.56°, 48.36°, 54.5° and 70.74°) are observed. However, the tetragonal CeAlO3 structure is observed only in the 5Ni@20CeO2-Al2O3 catalyst. It can be clearly seen that in the catalysts with low cerium oxide content, the cerium aluminate structure was not detected. In high temperatures within a reducing atmosphere, CeO2 supported on γ-Al2O3 reacts to form CeAlO3, which is crucial for coke removal as indicated [55]. The XRD pattern of the CeO2-Al2O3 supports is also given in the Supporting Material. It is interesting that in the XRD pattern of catalyst supports containing only CeO2 and Al2O3, the peaks have matched with CeO2 and γ-Al2O3 structures in the Match XRD Program, and no CeAlO3 structure has been observed. The peaks in the pattern (Fig. 4) at 2θ: 28.70°, 33.09°, 47.49°, 56.44°, 76.85°, 79.17° and 88.48° belong to CeO2 structure [56]. This indicates that in the presence of nickel, catalysts with a high content of CeO2 react with alumina to form CeAlO3. In the XRD analysis of the MgO support (in Supporting Material), MgO (2θ: 56.09°, 60.11°, 78.28°, 83.74°) and Al2O3 peaks are observed. With the addition of nickel to the support, an elemental Ni (2θ: 44.48°, 51.72°, and 76.4°) peak has been observed in the structure in addition to these peaks ( Fig. 5). During the nickel addition, the MgO in the structure was preserved, and no MgAl2O4 structure was encountered. High calcination temperatures of catalysts increase the interaction of the nickel particles and lead to the formation of NiAl2O4. It was reported that the reduction temperature of the NiAl2O4 was much higher than the reduction temperature of the NiO [57]. On the other hand, in catalysts with high oxygen mobility, such as CeO2 or La2O3, prepared at high calcination temperatures, no NiAl2O4 structure has been encountered. It can be seen clearly that for nickel-impregnated Ni@SiO2-Al2O3, the presence of cristobalite-high SiO2 [58], elemental Ni, and Al2O3 were observed. To determine the crystal size of elemental nickel in the structure of the catalysts, the Scherrer equation was used. In the calculation of crystal size, the main characteristic peak of nickel was used, and the 2θ values are provided in Table 4. The crystal size of Ni° values obtained as a result of calculations using the Scherrer equation are given in Table 4. According to BET analysis, the mean pore diameters of the La2O3-Al2O3 catalysts are between 9 and 12 nm in Table 3. The crystal sizes of nickel, calculated from Scherrer equation, are between 21 and 40 nm for La2O3-Al2O3 catalysts. These crystal sizes are larger than the average pore diameter of La2O3-Al2O3, supporting that significant fraction of nickel was deposited on the external surface of the La2O3-Al2O3 materials. In addition, it is observed that as the amount of lanthanum oxide in the catalyst content increases, the crystal size of nickel also increases. It is believed that with the increase in the amount of lanthanum oxide, more pores of the alumina support close, causing nickel to accumulate on the surface instead of entering the structure in the pores. Among the catalysts containing 10 % by weight of metal oxide (MgO, CeO2, La2O3), the smallest crystal size was observed in the 5Ni@10CeO2-Al2O3 catalyst. SEM-EDS analysis was performed to determine the chemical composition of the synthesized catalysts. The analysis results given in Table 5 suggested that the targeted metal loading was mostly achieved. Differences in the EDS results from the targeted values were probably due to nonuniform metal/metal oxide distribution among the catalysts. 3.2 Activity test results A set of catalytic activity tests were performed within a reaction period of 6 h at 800°C. The performances of the synthesized catalytic materials were evaluated in terms of Diesel conversion, and product distribution of H2, CO2, CO, CH4, and H2 selectivity. In order to estimate the catalytic performance, a blank experiment is conducted by introducing the Diesel fuel to the stainless-steel reactor under the same experimental conditions (800 °C and Steam/Carbon: 6) in the absence of any catalyst. Due to the nature of the Diesel fuel, the thermal decomposition of the fuel to olefinic and paraffinic compounds (methane, ethylene, ethane, propylene, propane, etc.) happens at elevated temperatures. Therefore, even in the absence of catalyst Diesel fuel transformed into various chemical species. Significant amount of methane and ethylene in the reactor effluent gas, indicates that the thermal cracking and ∝-scission reactions of Diesel is taking place resulting coke formation as well as other olefinic and paraffinic coumpounds. A considerable amount of hydrogen, carbon dioxide and carbon monoxide in the product stream may indicate the Boudouard reaction and Gasification reactions take place, causing coke formation as well. As a result of this experiment, it was found that there was no Diesel in the collected liquid, and product distribution is given in the Fig. 6. As a result, it is concluded that diesel fuel does not remain in its chemical state even in a catalyst-free environment under reaction conditions and breaks down into different components with coke formation. For this reason, the catalyst selected for the diesel steam reformer reaction ought to be resistant to coke formation and provides better conversion to the desired products. In the study of the kinetics of reversible reactions, thermodynamic analyses should be conducted. To determine the operating parameters of the main reaction, which is the steam reforming of Diesel, a thermodynamic analysis was carried out using the ASPEN HYSYS ® program, considering possible side reactions along with the main reaction. The Gibbs free energy minimization method is frequently used in the reforming reactions of hydrocarbons. During these analyses, it was assumed that the system was at constant temperature and atmospheric pressure, the gas mixture behaved according to the Peng Robinson equation of state, and there was no carbon deposition. For the feedstock Diesel composition in equilibrium calculations, carbon distributions from J.C. Amphlett's study were used [48]. The effect of the feed (steam/carbon ratio; S/C) molar ratio on product distribution in the steam reforming reaction of Diesel has been investigated using the ASPEN HYSYS program. During the activity tests of the catalyst, it is observed that some side reactions also occur in addition to the steam reforming reaction of Diesel. Fig. 7 presents the impact of the S/C ratio on product distribution in the steam-reforming reaction of Diesel. A temperature of 800°C has been selected for the analysis. As a result of the result, it has been observed that H2, CO, and CO2 product gases are formed. As the proportion of water in the feed gas increases, the equilibrium compositions of hydrogen and carbon dioxide increase, while the carbon monoxide composition decreases. The reason for this is the shift of the water gas reaction's equilibrium towards the products with increasing water content. The thermodynamic equilibrium analysis result of the effect of temperature on the steam reforming reaction of Diesel is given in Fig. 8. The analysis was carried out while keeping the S/C ratio constant at 6. In this study where the temperature scan was done between 700 and 1000°C, it is observed that there isn't a significant change in the amount of H2 as the temperature increases. However, the amount of CO slightly increases, and the amount of CO2 slightly decreases. Experiments were carried out at 800°C and with an S/C ratio of 6 to investigate the catalytic activities of the synthesized catalysts in the steam reforming of Diesel for hydrogen production. The average percentages in the product distribution obtained as a result of catalytic activity test values are given in Table 6. The products formed after the Diesel steam reforming reaction are mainly H2 and CO2, along with CH4, CO, C2H4, C2H6, C3H6, C3H8, and C4+. It can be clearly seen that H2 in the range of 67–68 mol% was obtained with complete Diesel conversion. According to thermodynamic equilibrium calculation approximately 67 % H2 production is expected. Therefore, the experimental results are consistent with the thermodynamic equilibrium. Traditionally catalytic activities of different materials are evaluated in conditions far from thermodynamic equilibrium. Kinetic working conditions may be achieved at lower conversion values by working at lower catalyst bed volume or higher space velocities. However, since the Diesel steam reformer reaction is a highly endothermic reaction, it occurs at very high temperatures such as 800°C. At these temperature values, almost full conversion is observed due to the nature of Diesel fuel that undergoes thermal decomposition to olefinic and paraffinic compounds (like ethylene, ethane, propylene, propane, etc.) even if part of it does not react catalytically. As a result, working in the kinetic region is not considered possible to work due to the difficulties caused by the fuel and reaction used within the scope of the study. For this reason, experimental outcomes such as the change in product distribution in long-term experiments and the amount of coke accumulated on the catalyst surface as a result of the reaction were used to compare different catalysts. Table 6 provides a comparative representation of the experimental data obtained from the steam-reforming reaction of Diesel using the synthesized catalysts. In the experiment conducted without a catalyst, approximately 0.30 L/min gas was produced, while with the catalyst, this value increased between 0.9 and 1 L/min. As a result of the experiments, it was determined that there was no Diesel in the collected liquid, and product distributions were obtained with 100 % conversion. In catalytic activity tests examining the effect of the amount of lanthanum oxide, it was observed that as the amount of lanthanum oxide increased, the amount of H2 decreased slightly. The highest %H2 amount was obtained with the 5La2O3-Al2O3 support, while the maximum produced gas amount (1 L/min) was achieved using the 10La2O3-Al2O3 support. Lanthanum oxide was added to the catalyst to minimize the amount of coke formed. However experimental results show that lanthanum oxide supported catalysts are not the leading catalyst in terms of coke durability. One probable reason for this result is the crystal size of the nickel particles added to the structure. On the contrary, the incorporation of La2O3 into the gamma alumina helped stability during the reforming reaction of Diesel. It can be seen in the H2 distribution graphic of lanthanium-supported catalysts in Fig. 9. To minimize coke formation, similar to the use of lanthanum oxide, an impregnation method has been applied to the gamma-alumina support for improvement with the use of cerium oxide. In the experiments where the effect of cerium oxide content (5,10, and 20 wt%) was investigated, as the amount of cerium oxide increased, there was a slight decreasing trend in the H2 amount; however, the 5Ni@10CeO2-Al2O3 catalyst disrupted this trend, showing high activity in the experiment. The % H2 product distribution graphs obtained as a result of the catalytic activity test of the catalysts are given in Fig. 9. As a result of six-hour experiments, it was observed that the support containing 10 % by weight of CeO2 among the CeO2-containing catalysts exhibited consistent activity. When comparing the results with the Lanthanum-supported catalysts, it is observed that the lanthanum-supported catalysts demonstrate more stable activity (Fig. 9). Similarly, among the lanthanum-supported catalysts, the best result was obtained with the support containing 10 % by weight of lanthanum. When compared with the experimental results of other synthesized catalysts, similar results have been achieved with CeO2 and La2O3 supports. In the test results, where the effect of the support was examined by keeping the nickel ratio constant, there was no significant change in terms of hydrogen production but the MgO support gave the lowest amount of gas produced. The mass balances based on carbon atom were made for the catalyst of concern that is synthesized with various different support materials. The calculations were made in the light of several significant assumptions such as a definite formula for the Diesel fuel is assumed as Heptadecane, C17H36 and constant flow rate of reactants and products at the steady-state condition which normally takes place an hour after the start of experiment. The results were computed by means several data taken from wet gas meter and gas chromatography output. The outcome of the mass balances shows that the percent error is within an acceptable margin of 5 % for each different experiment. Uncertainties in flow measurement devices and instrumentation deficiencies can be stated as possible causes of systematic errors. Additionally, the percent error is even further decrease when the carbon deposit as coke on the catalyst surface is taken into the consideration. The TGA results were used for the estimation of the carbon amount and were found to provide a minor improvement in the final results. To ensure data reliability, the activity test in the Diesel steam reforming reaction using the 5Ni@10CeO2-Al2O3 catalyst was repeated 3 times at 800°C and with an S/C ratio of 6. As a result of the experiments, the error graph obtained for each product is given in Fig. 10. The error bar in the Figure was calculated by taking the standard deviation of the all of experiments. As seen in the figure, a similar product distribution has been obtained in activity tests carried out with the 5Ni@10CeO2-Al2O3 catalyst. Reproducibility errors have been found to be 0.41 %, 0.09 %, and 0.35 % for CO, CO2, and H2, respectively. This result indicates that the catalytic activity tests are repeatable. 3.3 Time on stream test All of the catalytic performance tests reported above were carried out for a reaction period of six hours, using a 30 g catalyst. In order to observe catalyst deactivation at longer times, time-on stream tests extending to 6 days (total 36 hours) were performed using 30 g 5Ni@10La2O3-Al2O3. The tests were conducted in an on-off manner, running for 6 hours each day over a total of 6 days. During the activity test, water vapor was used for the heating and cooling processes of the catalytic bed. After the heaters reached the desired temperature while the water vapor flow continued, Diesel was fed. The cooling process was carried out by continuing the water vapor flow after stopping the Diesel feed and shutting down the electrical heaters. The system was shut down after a certain amount of water vapor passed over the catalyst surface. After the time on-stream test, the product distribution graph over time is given in Fig. 11. As a result of the experiment, a synthesis gas containing an average of 67 % H2, 0.2 % CH4, 16.6 % CO, and 18.2 % CO2 was produced. A similar product distribution was obtained in the short activity test of the same catalyst. Most importantly, the catalyst demonstrated stable activity with limited deactivation and low coke formation (1.33 wt%). When comparing the short-term and long-term tests, similar syngas production results were observed, along with approximately the same amount of carbon formation. This result indicates that a material has been successfully developed that could be a candidate for a commercial catalyst. 3.4 Coke formation and characterization of spent catalysts Thermogravimetric thermal analysis (TGA), XRD, and SEM tests were performed to obtain more information about coke formation and structural properties of spent catalysts. TGA was performed in a flow of dry air. Coke formation on the catalyst surface may take place as a result of methane cracking (CH4 → C + 2 H2), thermal cracking and Boudouard (2CO → C + CO2) reactions. Due to its exothermic nature, the Boudouard reaction becomes more significant at low reaction temperatures. However, methane and thermal cracking gains importance at elevated temperatures. In addition to this, olefinic and aromatic hydrocarbons formed after thermal Diesel can lead to coke formation. Specifically, ethylene (C2H4) is known to cause rapid coke formation during the reforming process [59]. Results of the TGA of the spent catalysts which were performed within a reaction period of 6 h at 800°C and atmospheric pressure are shown in Fig. 12 and Table 6. As shown in this figure, a weight loss was observed in the 400–800°C range, which is due to the combustion of coke deposited on the catalyst. Although the Boudouard reaction might also have some contribution to coke formation at 750°C, the main contributor was expected to be methane and thermal cracking reaction, at this temperature. Results showed more coke formation over Ni-impregnated La2O3 and MgO supports than CeO2 supports. The higher nickel crystal size of La2O3 supported Ni catalysts is the highly suspected cause for the outcome. The nickel crystal size in La2O3 supported catalysts is larger compared to CeO2 supported catalysts which is stated in Table 4. One reason for this is that agglomeration of nickel particles is highly likely to occur during the impregnation process. In parallel to this observation, coke deposition over Ni-based catalyst was also decreased as a result of CeO2 incorporation into the Al2O3 support material. The CeAlO3 structure plays a pivotal role in the elimination of coke. The tetragonal-shaped CeAlO3 is detected in the XRD analysis of the 5Ni@20CeO2-Al2O3 catalyst. The incorporation of CeO2 (20 % wt) into Al2O3 support decreased the amount of coke formation from 0.85 % to 0.26 %. This result proves that the CeAlO3 structure reduces coke formation. The highest amount of coke formation was observed over 5Ni@10La2O3-Al2O3. However, the catalytic performance of this catalyst was very stable among the other synthesized catalysts (Fig. 9). TGA results of the spent 5Ni@10La2O3-Al2O3 catalyst is given in Fig. 13 for short- and long-term activity tests. According to the analysis results, it is clearly seen that a similar amount of carbon formation is observed. After time on stream activity test which lasted six days, the amount of carbon accumulated on the catalyst surface was determined to be 1.33 wt%. A similar amount of carbon (1.38 wt%) was also detected in the short-life catalytic activity test. This suggests that the steam used in the startup and shutdown processes in time on stream activity tests might be removing the carbon from the catalyst surface. In the literature, some studies confirm this suggestion. Smith et al.l reported that the mitigation effect of the water on coke formation and deposition on the reactor catalyst in their study [60]. Huang et al.l also mentioned that the coke formed on a hot surface is removed by catalytic steam gasification to form hydrogen and carbon monoxide gases [61]. In the Diesel steam reforming reaction, the 5Ni@10CeO2-Al2O3 catalyst showed the highest activity among the Ni-based CeO2-Al2O3 catalysts. XRD patterns before and after the reaction for the catalyst are given in Fig. 14. Comparing the wide-angle XRD patterns before and after the reaction, no characteristic peak belonging to elemental carbon was observed. However, TGA of the spent 5Ni@10CeO2-Al2O3 catalyst showed that carbon formation was observed over the catalyst surface. So small amounts of carbon could not be detected with XRD because of detection limit of XRD device. The characteristic peaks belonging to nickel are also preserved after the reaction. However, intensities of the nickel characteristic peaks decrease after the reaction. This result indicates that metallic nickel has converted into nickel oxide. Similar results for Ni/SiO2 catalysts were also observed by Matsumura et al. [62]. Nevertheless, no diffraction peak belonging to NiO (JCPDS 4–835) was observed on the surface of the spent 5Ni@10CeO2-Al2O3 catalyst. The result showed that the particle size of NiO is smaller than detection limit of XRD device. A comparison of scanning electron microscope images of spent and fresh 5Ni@10La2O3-Al2O3 and 5Ni@10CeO2-Al2O3 catalysts are presented in Fig. 15. SEM image of 5Ni@10La2O3-Al2O3 catalyst (A) shows the presence of nickel particles with particle sizes ranging between 9 and 25 nm. Similarly, 5Ni@10CeO2-Al2O3 (Fig. 6-C) shows dispersed nickel particles with sizes in the range of 13 and 18 nm. Coke formation has not been observed in the SEM analysis results of spent catalysts (Fig. 15 B&D). Moreover, no structural changes were observed in the catalysts used, since SEM images of the used catalysts are identical to the fresh catalysts. 4 Conclusion The aim of this study is to operate a systematic comparative study using different promising promoters in terms of coke resistance in diesel steam reformer reactions. La2O3, SiO2, MgO, and CeO2 type oxides are selected candidates in order to ensure minimizing coke formation and resulting stable conditions for diesel steam reforming reaction to produce hydrogen rich syn-gas. The results show that catalytic performances of Ni incorporated La2O3, SiO2, MgO, and CeO2 supported catalysts were highly promising in the production of hydrogen-rich syngas. Results indicate the significant effect of metal oxide composition on the coke formation. CeO2 addition to alumina significantly improved the coke resistance of the catalysts. The incorporation of La2O3 into alumina helped stability during the reforming reaction of Diesel. During the long-term activity tests, steam was passed during heating and cooling processes of the catalytic bed. When comparing the short-term and long-term tests, similar syngas production results were observed, along with approximately the same amount of carbon formation. This result indicates that the steam used in heating and cooling processes decreased the amount of carbon formation as a result of Diesel reforming reaction. coredata.dc:description: The study aimed to investigate the impact of nickel-incorporating diverse metal oxides (MgO, La2O3, CeO2, SiO2) supported on alumina on the Diesel steam reforming reaction. Catalytic activity tests were performed within a reaction period of 6 h at 800°C and atmospheric pressure. The amount of catalyst is 30 gr in each experiment corresponding to a LHSV value of 0.2 hr−1. The tests proved that the performances of Ni-containing La2O3 and CeO2-supported catalysts were highly stable and active in steam reforming of Diesel, giving complete conversion. The incorporation of CeO2 (20 % wt) into Al2O3 support resulted in a significant reduction in the amount of coke formation from 0.85 % to 0.26 %. In order to investigate catalyst stability, time-on stream tests extending to 6 days, totaling 36 hours were performed using 5Ni@10La2O3-Al2O3. As a result of the long-term stability test, no deactivation has been observed under the test conditions despite very few amounts of carbon (1.33 wt%) formed. When comparing the short-term and long-term tests, similar syn-gas production results were observed, along with approximately the same amount of carbon formation.
